frontmatter.title: Environment and package management
frontmatter.description: Ensure reproducibility and avoid conflicts in your projects.

children.value: Python applications often rely on external libraries (packages) that are not included in the standard Python installation. A common challenge arises when
two projects require conflicting versions of the same library
because it expects an older version.
fragile development environment and complicates collaboration, testing, and deployment
The “It Works On My Machine” Problem

children.label: The “It Works On My Machine” Problem

children.value: Another common issue especially when working in a team:
code that works locally may fail in other environments
(e.g., on a teammate’s machine, a CI/CD pipeline, or production).
A developer might install dependencies globally (see above), leading to version mismatches elsewhere.
A project might rely on system-specific configurations or tools that are not replicated in other environments.
unreliable workflows, wasted time debugging, and frustration for teams
is a self-contained directory that isolates Python installations and packages for a specific project.
: Each project has its own Python interpreter and package versions.
: Upgrading one project’s dependencies does not affect others.
automate dependency management, ensuring consistent and reliable installations across environments.
: Automatically installs required packages and their dependencies.
: Locks package versions to avoid conflicts.
: Ensures the same environment can be recreated on any machine (e.g., using
Activate the virtual environment (steps depend on tool and OS used).
Install project-specific packages in the activated environment.

Make sure that the virtual environment is activated before installing any packages. When a virtual environment is active, the terminal prompt typically changes to indicate its name, often displayed in parentheses. For example:
You can also check which python is currently being used by running this command on your terminal/shell.
is a built-in virtual environment manager in Python (since Python 3.3)
environment (assuming you are already inside the
is the default package installer for Python
used in Python projects to list all the

required to run the project. It ensures that the same dependencies are installed consistently across different environments (e.g., development, testing, production) and helps collaborators or deployment systems recreate the project’s environment accurately.

The `pip freeze` command captures all installed packages and their versions in the current environment and sends the list to a file (e.g. `requirements.txt`).

This file can then be used to install the same packages in another environment.

Virtual environments and package managers are
. They solve the dependency problem, eliminate the “It Works On My Machine” dilemma, and ensure:
: Team members can work on the same project without conflicts.
: Code behaves consistently across development, testing, and production.
: Projects grow without breaking existing functionality.
By mastering these virtual environments and package managers, you’ll avoid common pitfalls and build robust, maintainable Python applications.
